contentrichtext.text: {{refimprove|date=December 2009}} '''Henry Dundas, 3rd Viscount Melville''' [[Order of the Bath|GCB]] (25 February 1801 – 1 Feb 1876)<ref>{{Rayment|m|3|date=February 2012}}</ref> was a British military leader. ==Early life== He was born eldest son of [[Robert Dundas, 2nd Viscount Melville]]. == Military career == {{unreferenced section|date=October 2010}} He joined the Army as a lieutenant in the 3rd (or Scots} Guards in 1819. He was promoted to captain of the [[Royal Ulster Rifles|83rd Regiment]] in 1824, major in 1826 and lieutenant-colonel in 1829. In 1837 he was active in suppressing the [[History of Canada#The Rebellions of 1837-38|Canadian rebellion]], after which he was appointed in 1841 colonel and [[aide-de-camp]] to [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Queen Victoria]]. He played a distinguished part in India as a brigadier-general in 1848–49, chosen to command the column sent from Bombay to co-operate with Lord Gough's army in the [[Second Anglo-Sikh War]]. He was second in command at the [[Battle of Multan|capture of Multan]] and then joined the main army with his force for the [[battle of Gujrat]]. He returned to England in 1850 and became 3rd Viscount Melville on his father's death in 1851. He continued his military career in Scotland from 1856 to 1860, in which year he was made governor of Edinburgh Castle. He was raised to the rank of general in 1868 and awarded the [[Order of the Bath]] in 1870. He died unmarried at Melville Castle, near Edinburgh in 1876. His younger brother, [[Richard Saunders Dundas]] was a prominent naval officer. == Parliament == He was a [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[Rochester (UK Parliament constituency)|Rochester]] from 1826 to 1830,<ref>{{Rayment-hc|r||date=February 2012}}</ref> and for [[Winchelsea (UK Parliament constituency)|Winchelsea]] from 1830 to 1831.<ref>{{Rayment-hc|w|4|date=February 2012}}</ref> == References == {{reflist}} *{{DNB|wstitle=Dundas, Henry (1801-1876) (DNB00)}} ==External links== *{{Hansard-contribs | mr-henry-dundas-1 | the Viscount Melville }} {{s-start}} {{s-par|uk}} {{s-bef | before = [[Thomas Hamilton, 9th Earl of Haddington|Lord Binning]]<br />[[Ralph Bernal]] }} {{s-ttl | title = [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Rochester (UK Parliament constituency)|Rochester]] | years = [[United Kingdom general election, 1826|1826]] – [[United Kingdom general election, 1830|1830]] | with = [[Ralph Bernal]] }} {{s-aft | after = [[George Child Villiers, 6th Earl of Jersey|Lord Villiers]]<br />[[Ralph Bernal]] }} {{s-bef | before = [[Henry Grey, 3rd Earl Grey|Viscount Howick]]<br />[[John Williams (1777–1846)|John Williams]] }} {{s-ttl | title = [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Winchelsea (UK Parliament constituency)|Winchelsea]] | years = [[United Kingdom general election, 1830|1830]] – 1831 | with = [[John Williams (1777–1846)|John Williams]] }} {{s-aft | after = [[Stephen Lushington (judge)|Stephen Lushington]]<br />[[John Williams (1777–1846)|John Williams]] }} {{S-reg|uk}} {{Succession box | title=[[Viscount Melville]] | before=[[Robert Dundas, 2nd Viscount Melville|Robert Dundas]] | after=[[Robert Dundas, 4th Viscount Melville|Robert Dundas]] | years=1851–1876 }} {{S-mil}} {{Succession box | title=[[List of Governors of Edinburgh Castle|Governor of Edinburgh Castle]] | before=?
